texts.shortText: Previously misidentified as Kellia rubra (a Europen species now re-named Lasaea adansoni).  Later reported as Lasaea adansoni turtoni, but as stated above the true L. adansoni is a Northern Hemisphere species and the South African subspecies is now recognized as its own separate species.

Tiny, fat bivalve with an oval outline and a distinct bulge behind hinge. Valves smooth, other than faint growth lines. Colour pale pink, usually with red-brown margins. Found among byssal threads of mussels or between barnacles or vermetid gastropod tubes on rocky shores.
Very small, shell length less than 5 mm.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to Mozambique.

A nestling species, often missed because of its small size, but in fact common on rocky shores, especially among byssal threads of mussels, or in crevices. Most members of this family are similarly associated with other larger invertebrates, especially filter-feeders, which may benefit the clams by generating water currents around them.

Very little is known about the feeding biology of this species, but almost all bivalves are filter-feeders, sucking in seawater and removing fine particulate material from it by passing the water though their enlarged sieve-like gills.

Has not been investigated for this species, but all members of this family are protandrous hermaphrodites - starting life as males and later changing to become females. Eggs are brooded with the mantle cavity, usually around the gills. In some species these are released as late-stage larvae, and in other species only at the crawling stage.

Can be confused with another small round species, Kellya rotunda, which also occurs in similar habitats. However, that species is larger (up to 11 mm), is usually found singly and is glossy white with an almost perfectly round shell.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 154, as Lasaea adamsoni turtoni).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 175, as Lasaea adamsoni turtoni).
